subject: testing interfaces
msgSnippet: ... Yes to both. My guess is that there is a core set of features that belong to Document and DocumentPool whose behavior you want to guarantee is consistent
messageBody:
>I have 2 interfaces "DocumentPool" and "Document" and multiple
>implementions of these (like HTMLPool, WordDocPool). The target is to
>link these (about 50.000) docs using different "rules".
>
>should i write my unit tests for each implementation or could i save
>time by writing one testcase to test the interface?

Yes to both.

My guess is that there is a core set of features that belong to Document and
DocumentPool whose behavior you want to guarantee is consistent across all
implementations. For that, you can use this strategy:

abstract DocumentTestCase
abstract Document getDocument()
void testX()
void testY()
...

DocumentImpl1TestCase extends DocumentTestCase
Document getDocument() { return someDocumentImpl1; }

DocumentImpl2TestCase extends DocumentTestCase
Document getDocument() { return someDocumentImpl2; }

and so on.

Here you run one test suite per implementation of Document, but the suites
have a common set of tests.

You may also have some behavior that is specific to a particular
implementation of Document. In this case, add tests for that behavior to the
test suite for that particular Document implementation. *Now* that test
suite covers both sets of features.

Remember: test behavior, not methods. Maybe you expose a method that you
don't need to expose...

Good luck.

JBR.
